Central, Eastern and Northern European Studies (Vancouver)

detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value:
Study the most widely spoken language in the Southern Hemisphere and the 5th most spoken native language in the world! The rich cultures of Brazil, Portugal and other Lusophone countries are incorporated in all materials used in class. 
See the full course overview: https://fhis.ubc.ca/course-description/PORT201   

Contact us here: https://fhis.ubc.ca/undergraduate-advising-contact-form/

instances.text: PSYC_V 207-001 - Contemporary Topics in Biological and Cognitive Psychology

detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value: Course topic: Psychology of Childbirth. This course examines different forms of human knowledge, alongside the cognitive and neural processes that shape this knowledge. Our knowledge about the process of giving birth comes from multiple sources, including scientific evidence, cultural beliefs, medical practices, and personal experience. The cognitive and neural processes by which we come to possess, use, and question the validity of this knowledge will be discussed.

instances.text: PSYC_V 277-001 - Behavioural and Neuroscientific Research Methods

detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value: note - labs for Psyc 277 will be manually assigned to one of the following times Wed 4-6 , Th 2-4, Th 4-6,  Fri 12-2

detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value:
Delivery Mode -This is a hybrid course. Students are expected to meet in-person on the days and times listed. In addition, course content will be delivered asynchronously.  ​

Waitlist Policy -All waitlists will follow a first come, first serve policy, unless specified otherwise. Once a course is full, its status will be changed to “Waitlist” and students who register will be automatically added to the waitlist.

instances.text: RGST_V 200-101 - Introduction to the Study of Religion

detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value:
Course Description:
This course takes a comparative, cross-cultural, and interdisciplinary approach to humans’ engagement with the sacred. It examines religions as complex systems that share certain fundamental common features. The primary focus in this course is not theology, but practice: what people do and why they do it. Additionally, the class examines how spirituality fits into the broader context of everyday human life. While we will examine a wide variety of religions, this course is not designed to study each religion in depth. In a time of religious dynamism and conflict, this course is designed to make you aware of others’ worldviews and religious systems, to encourage critical thought about religious belief and practice, and to promote confidence in learning from religious diversity.

detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value:
From medieval courtly love to baroque murderous passion, discover amazing tales of romance-language literature, featuring French, Italian and Spanish fiction. 
See the full course overview: https://fhis.ubc.ca/course-description/RMST201   

Language of Instruction: English 

Contact us here: https://fhis.ubc.ca/undergraduate-advising-contact-form/

instances.text: RMST_V 202-101 - Intro to Lit and Cult of the Romance Wld II: Mod to Post-Mod

detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value:
Italian Mafia Movies. The representational complexities, intentions, and agendas of the mafia movie genre by conducting a formal film analysis, while attending to the socio-historical and cultural contexts. Please register as RMST 202.  
ITAL 234 and RMST 202 are taught in the same classroom at the same time by the same instructor. All students must register in RMST 202.

See the full course overview: https://fhis.ubc.ca/course-description/RMST202  

Language of Instruction: English 

Contact us here: https://fhis.ubc.ca/undergraduate-advising-contact-form/

detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value:
This course is where students really become conversationalists in Russian. It fosters intermediate and advanced use of Russian language about students’ free time activities, the arts and music, relationships, leisure and travel, and personal background. By now, students are equipped with more than 800 words and phrases to use confidently in diverse conversational settings.

Sample syllabus here. 

Interested in other courses within the Department of Central, Eastern and Northern European Studies? Click here.

Boolean logic can be expressed using AND, OR, NOT, and (). 
Exact phrases can be surrounded by double quotation marks. 
Example: ("software engineer" OR computer science) AND ~manager~.
